author: Ben DiPietro
title: Corruption Currents: Ex-Chinese Official Gets Life for Bribery - Risk & Compliance Journal. - WSJ
text:
0 COMMENTS In this image taken from a video footage run by China's CCTV via AP Video, former political high-flyer Sun Zhengcai, center, is seen during his sentencing at the intermediate court in Tianjin, China, on Tuesday. Photo: CCTV via AP Video
A daily roundup of corruption news from across the Web. We also provide a daily roundup of important risk & compliance stories vi a our daily newsletter, The Morning Risk Report, which readers can sign up for here . Follow us on Twitter at @WSJRisk.
Bribery:
Sun Zhengcai, once considered a possible successor to Chinese President Xi Jinping, was sentenced to life in prison on Tuesday for a bribery conviction. (AFP, NPR, Bloomberg)
A New York business owner was found guilty of bribery. (HVNN)
The bribery trial of a Nigerian government official continues . (Vanguard, Punch)
Money Laundering:
Former Pakistan Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif is under investigation for alleged money laundering. The article contained no comment from the former prime minister. (ET)
Italian prosecutors are investigating allegations of fraud and money laundering at a Formula One race . (Wheels24, PlanetF1)
Can you identify the clues money laundering is occurring? (Slate)
Not everyone is convinced reforms to shed light on business ownership in the U.K. and its territories will lead to a reduction in money laundering. Some say it will worsen the problem. (Guardian, ES)
Cybercrime/Privacy:
Credit-monitoring firm Equifax released to Congress more details about its data breach last year. (CNET, Hill)
Lawmakers in Rwanda are debating a new cybersecurity law that would add to the list of crimes that can be prosecuted. (NT)
Concern continues to grow over the high cost of cybercrime in Africa. (Africa.com)
Japan and Estonia have agreed to work together on cybersecurity issues. (Janes)
Fast-food chain Wendy’s Philippines disclosed a data breach that involved customer information. (Rappler)
Sanctions:
President Donald Trump said the U.S. is abandoning the Iran nuclear agreement and will reinstate sanctions on Iran. Who will lose the most in Iran now that the U.S. is pulling out of the nuclear pact? Iran says it’s ready for what comes next and has been ramping up oil exports ahead of any new sanctions. How will Europe react ? (USAT, NYT, NYT, WP, CNBC, CNN)
Can Russia and China negate the impact of new U.S. sanctions on Iran? North Korean leader Kim Jong Un is watching what Mr. Trump does. Most Americans say the U.S. should remain in the deal. (Fox, CNN, CNN)
The U.S. Treasury Department’s Office of Foreign Assets Control, the main office for enforcing U.S. sanctions, remains understaffed . (DB)
Russia’s state-controlled oil company Rosneft PJSC, suffering from western sanctions, may be using a non-sanctioned bank to try to get around the restrictions. Russia may target U.S. meat producers with new sanctions.(Bloomberg, GMN)
Transparency:
A senior official in Malta reportedly ordered the backdating of documents relating to trusts he established in New Zealand. (AFR)
A law firm settled its Paradise Papers lawsuit with two media outlets that published details of offshore tax deals disclosed in the document dump. (Guardian)
General Anticorruption:
A judge in Brazil known for fighting corruption won’t run for president. (Reuters)
The mayor of an Israeli city says a corruption investigation against him is the result of his opponents trying to discredit him. (ToI)
Government agencies in Kenya pledged to work more closely to fight corruption. (CN)
Supporters of efforts in Guatemala to fight corruption say they won’t be deterred by a U.S. senator’s decision to put a hold on $6 million in funding. (KPVI)
